text: TC Boyle is one of America's most
prolific and inventive novelists the
author of 20 works of fiction he sat
down with me at the Times and we had a
talk about his career his interests his
new novel the women about Frank Lloyd
Wright and the women who loved him a
book partly inspired by the Frank Lloyd
Wright house the TC Boyle himself as
inhabited for 16 years
Tom Boyle tell me why you like giving
readings and doing interviews like this
not many novelists as distinguished as
you are would confess to that well Sam
it's because I'm a natural-born ham
don't forget I used to front my own rock
and roll band I love to perform from my
work I don't call it reading I call it a
performance because really Dickens did
perform it has the connotation of you
know school and boring and you know kids
read books today because they're a
required assignment in school I don't
know if they read books outside of
school because they're subversive and
they're fun you know as much as we
intellectualize their literature really
it is an entertainment all art is an
entertainment at root you know it's it's
not a homework assignment it's not
something boring so I love to get out on
stage and give a show especially for
high school kids it might be in the
audience and you just give them a good
show and they enjoy it and they think
you know literature stuff it ain't that
bad really
well let's talk about the women it's a
novel in many ways about architecture
the architecture of the work itself it
has an unusual time sequence it moves
backward in time but at the center of it
is Frank Lloyd Wright and the many women
in his life but you have a personal
connection to Frank Lloyd Wright maybe
the closest anyone can have yeah it's
true and I have to fess up Sam yeah I
live in his first California house and
I've lived in it for 16 years now and
I'm happy to be there and when I moved
in I knew something of Frank Lloyd
Wright but one of the beauties of what
I'm doing is whenever I want to find
something out I write a book about it or
a story about it and I'd been brooding
about this one for a long while but you
also did a lot of research
she said book your own books are not
homework B did some homework for this
menu at all though
Bogg Rafi s course you studied the life
closely he said it the architecture
closely yes I did and but it was a
delight it was something I wanted to
know about because of the house that I'm
living in the figure I've heard is there
something like a thousand books have
been written about Frank Lloyd Wright in
his architecture the thing I didn't know
was what a cult there is around this man
it's astonishing
and yet you capture that cult to some
extent the feeling of the cult that
surrounded right in his own time
particularly the women in his life what
was it that attracted them to him you
know as a satirist of course I'm always
looking at the the underside of the icon
even though I admire him greatly I'm
always worried about and this isn't a
lot in a line of succession of other
books I've done the inner circle about
Alfred C Kinsey and the road to
wellville.shoot collage I'm worried
about gurus you know I I grew up here in
America in a free society doing and
saying anything I want no one has ever
said no to me you know and it's a very
distrustful of gurus of people who say
come to me and I will absolve your sins
give over yourself to me I stand back
from that and so when I find a figure
like Frank Lloyd Wright who wasn't
horribly magnetic I just want to see
what else there was there how what is
the effect on on you if you give
yourself up to his regime and so the
narrator Tadashi Sato is it a printer
company's apprentice and a president at
Harvard and MIT yes and so we have also
his women that entered into his sphere
as a as a classic narcissist this man
didn't really consider other people to
have value except as they entered into
his regime the same was true of Kinsey
and of Kellogg this kind of character
really fascinates me because of course
many novelists their life has done me
I'm a saint
and so I it's it's a kind of personality
that I like to explore
Tom another question you mentioned the
sequence of novels this belongs you've
written novels about Alfred Kinsey about

family yes well as well yes the Great

American component is there an American

something of course of course there is
in those times and it's the reason I
love these times of the early part of
the last century there were unexplored
jungles on climb mountains the world was
much bigger there were far fewer people
we Americans could do anything we could
create the repr corporation we could we
could create great architecture we could
have a battle creek sanitarium and heal
the world and make everybody live
forever there's a kind of snake oil
peddler and in all of these guys but
there's also a progressive urge in them
to to change things and I mean that is
uniquely American and further another
thing interested me about all the fourth
figures you've mentioned here now
including the McCormick's is that each
established a society within the society
a kind of idyllic utopian kind of
society that fascinates me too
what are you working on now you've told
